messageBody:
ABSTRACT:

InjectingRunner allows a test-suite to be injectable. An arbitrary number of implementations may inject into the suite, and the full suite is independently run for each implementation.

USE-CASE:

I recently wrote an interface that mimics a Table, a 2-dimensional array. I anticipated having a couple implementations of this table, and wanted each to be compliant with the tests written for my interface.
Currently, I have to write tests for each implementation. Instead, I wanted to be able to write one test-suite that fully defines the interface, and simply say "Test using these Table implementations."
Furthermore, I imagine that if I ever distribute my interface, third-parties may choose to implement their own Tables. They would either have to write their own tests, or simply trust that they didn't make any mistakes. Instead, they can simply inject their implementations into my test suite, in the exact same way I'm doing now.

EXAMPLE:

As a quick example, you could have the following test suite:

// ListTest.java (imports omitted for brevity)

// NoopRunner does nothing. This was the easiest way to use familiar syntax while not having to explicitly omit this class every time I want to test.
@RunWith(NoopRunner.class)
public class ListTest {
@Injected
public List<String> list;

@Test
public testList() {
list.add("A");
assertThat(list.size(), is(1));
}

}

// ArrayListTest.java (imports omitted for brevity)

@RunWith(InjectingRunner.class)
@InjectTest(injectedValue=ArrayList.class, testClass= ListTest.class)
public class ArrayListTest {
// Do nothing; this is sufficient to create our test.
}


// LinkedListTest.java (imports omitted for brevity)

@RunWith(InjectingRunner.class)
@InjectTest(injectedValue=LinkedList.class, testClass=ListTest.class)
public class LinkedListTest {
// Do nothing; this is sufficient to create our test.
}

And that's it. It's pretty experimental right now, and only does rudimentary validation, but it works, and generates sensible output -- in Eclipse, ArrayListTest appears to own the methods actually in ListTest.

HOW TO USE:

It's very easy to retrofit an existing test suite to use this new injection runner; it boils down to removing the line in the @Before method and adding the annotations. Once that's complete, your test framework can be generic to any subclass of that variable.

DETAILS:

Internally, InjectingRunner is rather simple. It extends Runner and creates a BlockJUnit4Runner for the referenced test-suite. That underlying class handles finding the tests in the class, and running them.
Injection is done by override withBefores, and just adding another Statement before any @Before's run. Since it's just using the standard stuff in the standard Runner, everything works as normal (You can use @Before, @BeforeClass, and everything else you'd use in a normal test-suite).

FINAL THOUGHTS:

I was wondering if there was any interest in the source for this, or if I've foolishly reimplemented something already in JUnit. This has some similiarities to the Theories runner, but that was too different to work well with this.

- Aaron Faanes
